petitioner.name: AMERICAN TRUCKING ASSOCIATIONS, INC., AND USF HOLLAND, INC.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: We'll hear argument now in American Trucking Associations v. Michigan Public Service Commission and a companion case. Mr. Digges.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, it -- it does for trucks that want to deliver things within the State of Michigan. It doesn't for anybody else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: It would have that -- it certainly has that tendency. Do we have -- do we know in fact what the effect is? Is it deterring anybody? How many trucks does it affect?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course, it also -- I mean, you say it -- it favors the in-state -- intrastate carrier because if you're doing nothing but intrastate carriage, you -- you amortize the $100 over many more miles, whereas the interstate carrier, much of whose business is out-of - state, doesn't do that. On the other hand, you can certainly argue that -- that this tax discriminates against intrastate carriers in -- in another respect, that is to say, interstate carriers who -- who do nothing within the State do not pay it, whereas the -- the Michigan carrier that does a lot of interstate business but if he does one piece of intrastate business -- interstate business, he still pays it. Isn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, it's not so much that you necessarily can do it, but it -- it sort of interrupts the -- the kind of the a priori reasoning and you're thrown back on a -- on -- on a practical effects analysis under Pike.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But may I ask this question? Suppose you have an interstate carrier that does 100,000 miles of business in Michigan and you have an intrastate carrier that does a 100,000 miles of business in Michigan. They both say the -- pay the same tax, don't they?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: They would both pay the same tax, both the intra and the interstate. Now, that doesn't sound to me like discrimination against either one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, but I'm just saying if the intrastate and interstate carriers both have the same intrastate mileage, they both pay the same tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but you might have an intrastate carrier that does a smaller amount of mileage, only 50,000 miles, and an interstate carrier that pays - - does 100,000 miles. They both pay the same tax too. And everybody is treated alike on their intrastate business.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And the tax only operates on intrastate business.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it seems to me you should have introduced some evidence on that point. I mean, it -- it really is an assumption of your unfairness argument that purely intrastate carriers do significantly more intrastate business than interstate carriers who choose to do some interstate business. Now, does that strike you as self-evident? It does not need any - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- demonstration?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Wouldn't we be better able to decide this question after a trial rather than speculation on both sides?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Well, Nippert was over 100 years ago, wasn't it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: It seems like 100 years ago. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Digges, this -- the - - the -- there was a question about the ramifications of the position that you're presenting. That is, there are many situations in which there is some kind of licensing fee that is imposed on everyone, the same dollar amount, although some people who are licensed will be doing business in other States and have to get licenses there as well. The example that was featured in the -- in the briefs on the other side of the lawyer who is licensed, say, in Massachusetts and also in D.C. does not get any break on his D.C. Bar admission because he is also admitted in Massachusetts, and in fact, does most of his practice out-of-state, out of the District.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The Scheiner case didn't 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 make a distinction based on in-state activity. I thought that that -- that flat fee was applicable to every motor carrier that went on the roads in Pennsylvania.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Very well, Mr. Digges. Mr. Hanson.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: It's the same fee we're talking about.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: But a different theory of invalidity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Intrastate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Okay, and yours is the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 interstate fee.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And your fee applies to all Michigan-plated vehicles. Am I correct about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Do -- do I understand that the two distinctions in what is done with the -- or the way the fee is collected and what's done with it is that the -- the fee is charged against the -- is it the operator as opposed to the owner, if there is a distinction? Is -- is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: The carrier.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That's the term I should use.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Which may not be the owner. And number two, as I understand it, as distinct from the registration fee, this fee goes to a different State department. Is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Now, let -- that's -- that's a premise for a question I want to ask you, and the question is in economic effect, is there any difference really between charging this $100 fee with those differences from the registration fee and simply jacking up the registration fee by $100? Would there -- would there be any economic difference to the -- to the public or -- or indeed even to the carriers if they simply jacked up the -- the registration fee by $100? Because the -- the registration fee is passed on to the carrier, if it's not the owner, and the carrier -- it doesn't make any difference to the carrier whether the -- whether the State diverts the $100 up front or -- or divides the -- the registration fee after it's paid. So is there any economic difference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, but that shows -- that -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 maybe I don't understand. That -- that tells us what happens to the money after it's paid, but it doesn't make any difference to the person who is paying the money, does it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Except that he only has to pay in one place, and -- and if they - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- increase the registration fee, he'd only have to pay in one place, once.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Who -- who sets the fee for the plating?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- you could have -- unlike the -- the fee, the $10 fee, that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the Federal cap, this would -- for plating it could be anything each individual State chooses it to be? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Sure, but it -- so -- so regardless of what Michigan does with the apportioned amounts, the amount it charges to the -- to the owner, in the case of the -- the plating fee, is -- is simply set by the State of Michigan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So what -- and -- and the - - the virtue of the apportionment is that the -- that the owner or the -- or the owner, I guess in this case, does not have to pay fees in 49 other States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But he doesn't -- it doesn't matter to -- that's the value to him. It doesn't matter to him how they apportion whatever that fee is that Michigan charges.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But who -- I mean, is -- that's -- that's fine as a matter of administration, but in terms of the -- the end effect on the person who has to pay it and on the consumers to whom it is ultimately passed on, what difference does it make?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can I ask a quick question? The -- there are three things. Were -- were you finished?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, I don't think he -- I didn't - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Sorry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't understand your answer. If you were finished, I don't understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask this question? Supposing the -- Michigan changed its system and said we're going to charge you $90 for -- as a plating fee. We're only talking about vehicles that are plated in Michigan. We're going to charge you $90 for a plating fee and now we're going to take 10 -- what used to part of the $100 and another $10 registration fee. Would that be permissible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay. What if he said $20 instead of $10?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But that -- that assumes it's an SSRS charge, and the State denies that it -- it has anything to do with SSRS. Don't you have to establish that it's part of the SSRS program?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay, but what -- what if the State says, you can enter -- enter into interstate activities for nothing? We're simply going to increase the registration fee by $100. Couldn't the State do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So this is pure formalism.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Maybe they sought to but maybe they didn't succeed. As I read the statute, it -- it really applies to the -- the limitation of $10 only to those fees that are SSRS fees, and these are not. So maybe there's -- there's a hole in the Federal statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You're trying to make the Federal statute work sensibly, but - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- I hate to tell you, but not all statutes work sensibly.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Hanson.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Your time is expired.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Mr. Boynton, we'll hear from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It sure does make sense to me, though. Surely it's the case that a company that does nothing but intrastate Michigan business will, by and large, log in many more miles intrastate than a company which does interstate business but part of its business is intrastate Michigan business. I -- I just -- it seems to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 me obvious that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It -- it's the case that a company that does only intrastate Michigan business logs all of its miles on -- in Michigan. Right? No miles outside of Michigan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And it seems to me it's obvious that a -- a company that does interstate business does not log all of its miles in -- in Michigan, and likely - - likely -- very likely does -- does less miles in Michigan than -- than a purely intrastate Michigan trucker. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Is it difficult to apportion the intrastate fee based on the number of miles traveled intrastate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Does it make any difference how high the -- the fee is set? If it were $10,000 a 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 truck, does that raise any concerns that are different?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you defend that position, that -- that it doesn't violate the Commerce Clause so long as it's a fee not a tax?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Whenever it's a fee, not a tax, you immediately go to Pike Church.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I know. I know that's what they said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I found it very strange.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: What makes it a fee instead of a tax other than the court saying so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You could say the same about a tax. You could say, you know, you only have to pay this tax if you operate in Michigan. You don't want to operate; you don't have to pay it. And you could also say unless you pay the tax, you cannot operate in Michigan. Does that make it a tax or a fee?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'd like to get back just for a moment - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- to the answer you gave about apportionment because I wasn't quite sure I understood the answer. You said, well, apportionment is very difficult. What are you supposed to do? What are you -- what's the base? Well, and you said, should we apportion against -- between in-state and out-of-state, and I would think the answer is yes. That's the whole point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And if we're talking about mileage here, maybe this is something that's eminently susceptible of apportionment. Now, it may be that administratively this is just too expensive. That may be -- that may be a very valid argument. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 But so far as saying that there's no basis for apportionment, I didn't understand your answer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It would be difficult to do administratively. But -- just because of the cost of collecting all the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That -- that -- I agree that that is expensive. However, it seems to me that it would be easier to do it with trucks which have miles than with - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- than with, say, attorneys or accountants or whatever.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But the American Trucking Association is -- is willing to be thrown into the -- into the briar bush apparently. It certainly involves no -- no difficulty for your Michigan intrastate truckers. All of their miles are intrastate. And the plaintiffs here say we're -- we're willing to -- you know, to provide figures showing how much of our carriage was -- was exclusively 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 intrastate if you want to apportion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask this question? Is the fee payable before the -- a carrier may engage in business or is it after the carrier has paid? Is it -- is it like a tax that's paid after the year is out?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: If you had to pay it before, there would be no way to calculate it ahead of time because nobody would have had any mileage. Isn't that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: If you have to pay it before the year begins and before you're allowed to engage in the business, you would have no way of measuring the number of miles you're going to travel during the -- the ensuing year.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I suppose that's the same thing for the $10 fee for the whatever the acronym is there. That's paid at the beginning of the year, isn't it? And it has to be apportioned among the States. And you don't know how to apportion it at the beginning of the year.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right, right. But I'm saying the same problem arises when you do any apportioning.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's like a 3-day fishing license.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How -- how does that work in -- in practice? Is it easily accessible? Suppose the company - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- wants to fill up its truck and -- and it said, well, this is going to be -- the only haul this season for me, so I want the 3-day permit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: This -- this applies only to operations that are both licensed and registered in Michigan. Is that so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Right, right, yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Are you going to address the Mid-Con question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Are you going to address the Mid-Con question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, what's the point of the limitation in SSRS to $10 if the State can impose any additional fee it wants just by calling it a different name?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Of course, it -- it does. Number one, it's somewhat suspect at the outset because it applies only to interstate travel.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And -- and then the -- the other vehicles pay $100 for the -- for the in-state fees, and so this seems to me that -- that on -- on its face shows that it's like a registration fee.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's -- that's the problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's the problem because here we're dealing with the fee to be paid by the people who are plated in Michigan, and it looks like that $100 is the fee for them. Well, let me -- I have a question. I'm trying to test this. Suppose that I have a company in Maine. All right? And I have -- I decide all my -- I -- I have all Maine plates, by the way. And I decide I want my - - now, let's -- one word is license plates. I'm going to talk about plating. Another word is the ICC insurance. Let's call it a decal. And the third kind of a concept is whatever you refer to in your statute by a fee. All right? The $100.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Now, suppose in Maine what I do with my trucks is I say I want Michigan to be my home State for purposes of -- what do you call it? The SS?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes. And so I go to Michigan, and now I pay all the registration fees here. Do I get a -- a certificate of some kind, a decal or something to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 show I did it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, yes. So -- that's right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Do I get a decal after I go through all this procedure? You have a whole form. I pay $6 for Alabama. I pay $2 for Idaho, and -- but -- but I do it all in one shopping place which happens to be Michigan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Then do I get a little certificate to put on the truck to say I did it. I -- I registered my ICC decal everywhere.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, it's not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know for Michigan. But I have to pay. But Michigan is my -- I can't ask the question until I get clear on this.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Don't -- when I -- when I go under this -- this 49 U.S.C. 14504 and I choose a home State - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- and I make all the relevant payments to that State, but they distribute, don't I get a piece of paper saying I did it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Fine. Now, I'm now plated in Michigan, and I make Michigan my home State for this. And I go and I make -- I say, Michigan, I'm going to give you this big check to distribute, but the amount I'm putting here for Michigan, by the way, is zero. And you say pay me $100. No. I'm not going to do it. So I haven't paid them the $100. I haven't paid Michigan everything, but I paid $2 for Idaho. Do I get the decal or don't I?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Excellent. Now, if I don't get the decal, because I didn't pay the $100, then that $100 is a charge that falls within the SSI. It is a charge for a decal which shows that I registered the ICC and my insurance because otherwise, if it weren't, you'd give me the decal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm talking about a fee. I'm trying to -- oh, fine. If there's no fee charged and I didn't pay the $100 and I didn't pay anything else, you'd give me the decal. But you said you wouldn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Boynton, may I just -- may I just ask this question? Is part of your position that the Federal statute does not prevent Michigan from waiving the $10 fee on -- for this particular purpose?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Right. So that -- but you're saying to Justice Breyer then is they have waived the $10 and they do it to a narrow class, those vehicles who are plated in Michigan because they've already charged them $100, a very heavy charge for the privilege of being plated. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is that right? Let me -- let me -- I wanted to ask this question to see whether it's vehicle-specific. Suppose I have nine trucks. They're Michigan-plated, so I have to pay $100 for each of the nine.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Now, suppose I -- suppose I only pay the fee for eight of them. What happens?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No. I've paid for eight, but I haven't paid for the ninth. As I read the Michigan law, it says shall not operate any motor vehicle upon or over the highways of this State while any of the fees imposed by this act remain unpaid. Now, if -- if I can't operate the other eight because I haven't paid for the nine, that 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 sounds to me like a vehicle-specific tax.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean -- I mean the opposite. It's -- it's not vehicle-specific.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I've paid for the eight, and I can't operate at all because I haven't paid for the ninth.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me how it reads. Am I reading the law wrong? It says, shall not operate any motor vehicle while any of the fees imposed by this act remain unpaid.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: At all. So it's not really vehicle-specific.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, the computation is vehicle-specific, but you're using all the vehicles as hostage for the payment of -- of any shortfall. That's what you're doing, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So it's carrier-based. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do you place any reliance in this scheme on the fact that the only people subject to it are people who have their principal place of business in Michigan?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And -- and anyone can choose to do that? I mean, going back to Justice Breyer's example, anybody can say, well, I think I'd like to be plated in Michigan even though I operate in -- in other States. My principal place of business is in another State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No. I'm just asking about what you do in Michigan. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You really can do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You -- you can plate your whole fleet in Michigan under those circumstances.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Boynton. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Mr. Stewart, we'll hear from you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That seems to me really to go back on -- on Scheiner. And I thought we tried to get 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 away from deciding Commerce Clause questions on the basis of whether it is interstate commerce or local commerce, you know, the original package doctrine and things that succeeded it. And you're -- you're just dragging back in this -- this inquiry into whether it's really interstate or -- or rather local.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, it could. I mean, if - - if this -- this truck is making one -- one haul, it's carrying some goods from Texas to -- to Maine, but some other goods it picks up along the way within Tennessee and just carries it to another place within Tennessee, and then it picks some other goods in New Jersey, carries it elsewhere to New Jersey, you're going to be taxed. It seems to me it's -- it's one trip. We never used to -- used to divide railroads on the basis of well, the ICC has jurisdiction over just the interstate portions and -- and the two stops within a State can be regulated by the State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'd like to know the text you rely on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: For -- for preemption, the text of the current statute that you rely on.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: 13501 deals just with SSRS.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask this question? Because I know your time is short. Supposing Michigan imposed a new $10 fee per -- and it identified it precisely as in order to comply with that statute and then reduced its present plating fee from $100 to $90, would that be permissible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm not saying -- they reduced to $90 the plating fee, but then they enacted a new $10 fee specifically designed to comply with the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Could they do that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The $90 is for plating. It 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 said only -- only Michigan-plated vehicles pay the $90. Everybody else -- everybody -- and everybody also pays the $10.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Where does it say that? Let - - let me come back to the -- to the section of the statute you're quoting. You didn't finish the sentence. It says that it's not an unreasonable burden when the State registration is completed under standards of the Secretary under subsection (c). Subsection (c) is entitled SSRS, Single State Registration System.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Briefly.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Stewart. Mr. Digges, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Digges.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE REHNQUIST
speakers.text: The case is submitted.
